answer_html: \(f(x_r)=r\) as desired.(Note that this final justification is included only as a sanity check and is not needed in a solution to obtain full marks).
answer_latex:
$f(x_r)=r$ as desired.(Note that this final justification is included only as a
sanity check and is not needed in a solution to obtain full marks).
hints_html: Remember that bijective is the same as being both injective (one-to-one) and surjective (onto).
hints_latex:
Remember that bijective is the same as being both injective (one-to-one)
and surjective (onto).
hints_raw: Remember that bijective is the same as being both injective (one-to-one) and surjective (onto).
sols_html:
We will first show that this function is injective.

Suppose that \(f(x) = f(y)\) for some \(x, y \in \mathbb{R} - \{1\}\). First, we note that if \(f(x) = 0\) then \(x= 0\). So we can suppose that \(x \neq 0 \neq y\). Then we would have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{2x}{x - 1} = \frac{2y}{y - 1} &\iff \frac{y - 1}{y} = \frac{x -1 }{x} \\ &\iff 1 - \frac{1}{y} = 1 - \frac{1}{x} \\ &\iff \frac{1}{y} = \frac{1}{x}\end{aligned}\]

which is true if and only if \(x = y\), and so the function is injective.

To show that the function is surjective, we need to “invert” the function. That is, we want to show that for each \(r \in \mathbb{R} - \{2\}\) that we can find some \(x_r\) so that \(f(x_r) = r\). Expanding this yields

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{2x_{r}}{x_{r} - 1} &= r\\ 2x_{r} &= r(x_{r}-1)\\ 2x_{r} &= rx_{r}-r\\ 2x_{r} -rx_{r} &= -r\\ x_{r}(2 -r) &= -r\\ x_{r} &= \frac{-r}{2-r}\\ x_{r} &= \frac{r}{r-2}\end{aligned}\]

Hence we can choose \(x_r = \frac{r}{r - 2}\). In such a case, we have

\[\begin{aligned} f(x_r) &= \frac{2\frac{r}{r - 2}}{\frac{r}{r - 2} - 1} \\ &= \frac{2\frac{r}{r - 2}}{\frac{r - (r - 2)}{r - 2}} \\ &= \frac{2r}{r - (r - 2)} = r\end{aligned}\]

as desired. (Note that this final justification is included only as a sanity check and is not needed in a solution to obtain full marks).

Recall that a function is bijective if and only if it has an inverse function, that is, a function \(\displaystyle g(x)\) such that both

\(\displaystyle f(g(x)) = x\)

and that

\(\displaystyle g(f(x)) = x\)

I claim that for

\(\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{2x}{x-1}\)

the function

\[\begin{aligned} g : \mathbb{R}-\{2\} &\to \mathbb{R}-\{1\}\\ x &\mapsto \frac{x}{x-2} \end{aligned}\]

is an inverse function for \(\displaystyle f(x)\). To prove this, we proceed directly. Notice that

\[\begin{aligned} f(g(x)) &= \frac{2(\tfrac{x}{x-2})}{(\tfrac{x}{x-2})-1} \\ &= \frac{2(\tfrac{x}{x-2})}{(\tfrac{x-x+2}{x-2})} \\ &= \frac{2x}{x-2} \cdot \frac{x-2}{2} \\ &= x\end{aligned}\]

and that

\[\begin{aligned} g(f(x)) &= \frac{\tfrac{2x}{x-1}}{(\tfrac{2x}{x-1})-2} \\ &= \frac{\tfrac{2x}{x-1}}{(\tfrac{2x-2(x-1)}{x-1})} \\ &= \frac{2x}{x-1} \cdot \frac{x-1}{2} \\ &= x\end{aligned}\]

and this completes the proof. To see where \(\displaystyle g(x)\) came from, check out solution 1.
sols_latex:
We will first show that this function is \emph{injective}.

Suppose that $f(x) = f(y)$ for some $x, y \in \mathbb{R} - \{1\}$.
First, we note that if $f(x) = 0$ then $x= 0$. So we can suppose that
$x \neq 0 \neq y$. Then we would have

\begin{align*}
\frac{2x}{x - 1} = \frac{2y}{y - 1} &\iff \frac{y - 1}{y} = \frac{x -1 }{x} \\
&\iff 1 - \frac{1}{y} = 1 - \frac{1}{x} \\
&\iff \frac{1}{y} = \frac{1}{x}
\end{align*}

which is true if and only if $x = y$, and so the function is injective.

To show that the function is \emph{surjective}, we need to ``invert''
the function. That is, we want to show that for each
$r \in \mathbb{R} - \{2\}$ that we can find some $x_r$ so that
$f(x_r) = r$. Expanding this yields

\begin{align*}
\frac{2x_{r}}{x_{r} - 1} &= r\\
2x_{r} &= r(x_{r}-1)\\
2x_{r} &= rx_{r}-r\\
2x_{r} -rx_{r} &= -r\\
x_{r}(2 -r) &= -r\\
x_{r} &= \frac{-r}{2-r}\\
x_{r} &= \frac{r}{r-2}
\end{align*}

Hence we can choose $x_r = \frac{r}{r - 2}$. In such a case, we have

\begin{align*}
f(x_r) &= \frac{2\frac{r}{r - 2}}{\frac{r}{r - 2} - 1} \\
 &= \frac{2\frac{r}{r - 2}}{\frac{r - (r - 2)}{r - 2}} \\
 &= \frac{2r}{r - (r - 2)} = r
\end{align*}

as desired. (Note that this final justification is included only as a
sanity check and is not needed in a solution to obtain full marks).

Recall that a function is bijective if and only if it has an inverse
function, that is, a function $\displaystyle g(x)$ such that both

$\displaystyle f(g(x)) = x$

and that

$\displaystyle g(f(x)) = x$

I claim that for

$\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{2x}{x-1}$

the function

\begin{align*}
g : \mathbb{R}-\{2\} &\to \mathbb{R}-\{1\}\\
x &\mapsto \frac{x}{x-2} 
\end{align*}

is an inverse function for $\displaystyle f(x)$. To prove this, we
proceed directly. Notice that

\begin{align*}
f(g(x)) &= \frac{2(\tfrac{x}{x-2})}{(\tfrac{x}{x-2})-1} \\
&= \frac{2(\tfrac{x}{x-2})}{(\tfrac{x-x+2}{x-2})} \\
&= \frac{2x}{x-2} \cdot \frac{x-2}{2} \\
&= x
\end{align*}

and that

\begin{align*}
g(f(x)) &= \frac{\tfrac{2x}{x-1}}{(\tfrac{2x}{x-1})-2} \\
&=  \frac{\tfrac{2x}{x-1}}{(\tfrac{2x-2(x-1)}{x-1})} \\
&= \frac{2x}{x-1} \cdot \frac{x-1}{2} \\
&= x
\end{align*}

and this completes the proof. To see where $\displaystyle g(x)$ came
from, check out solution 1.
sols_raw:
We will first show that this function is ''injective''.

Suppose that <math> f(x) = f(y)</math> for some <math> x, y \in \mathbb{R} - \{1\}</math>. First, we note that if <math>f(x) = 0</math> then <math> x= 0</math>. So we can suppose that <math>x \neq 0 \neq y</math>. Then we would have

:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{2x}{x - 1} = \frac{2y}{y - 1} &\iff \frac{y - 1}{y} = \frac{x -1 }{x} \\
&\iff 1 - \frac{1}{y} = 1 - \frac{1}{x} \\
&\iff \frac{1}{y} = \frac{1}{x}
\end{align}
</math>

which is true if and only if <math>x = y</math>, and so the function is injective.

To show that the function is ''surjective'', we need to "invert" the function. That is, we want to show that for each <math> r \in \mathbb{R} - \{2\}</math> that we can find some <math>x_r</math> so that <math>f(x_r) = r</math>. Expanding this yields

<math> 
\begin{align}
\frac{2x_{r}}{x_{r} - 1} &= r\\
2x_{r} &= r(x_{r}-1)\\
2x_{r} &= rx_{r}-r\\
2x_{r} -rx_{r} &= -r\\
x_{r}(2 -r) &= -r\\
x_{r} &= \frac{-r}{2-r}\\
x_{r} &= \frac{r}{r-2}
\end{align}
</math>

Hence we can choose <math> x_r = \frac{r}{r - 2}</math>. In such a case, we have

:<math>
\begin{align}
f(x_r) &= \frac{2\frac{r}{r - 2}}{\frac{r}{r - 2} - 1} \\
 &= \frac{2\frac{r}{r - 2}}{\frac{r - (r - 2)}{r - 2}} \\
 &= \frac{2r}{r - (r - 2)} = r
\end{align}
</math>

as desired. (Note that this final justification is included only as a sanity check and is not needed in a solution to obtain full marks).
Recall that a function is bijective if and only if it has an inverse function, that is, a function <math>\displaystyle g(x)</math> such that both

<math>\displaystyle f(g(x)) = x</math>

and that

<math>\displaystyle g(f(x)) = x</math>

I claim that for

<math>\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{2x}{x-1}</math>

the function

<math>
\begin{align} 
g : \mathbb{R}-\{2\} &\to \mathbb{R}-\{1\}\\
x &\mapsto \frac{x}{x-2} 
\end{align}
</math>

is an inverse function for <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math>. To prove this, we proceed directly. Notice that

<math>
\begin{align}
f(g(x)) &= \frac{2(\tfrac{x}{x-2})}{(\tfrac{x}{x-2})-1} \\
&= \frac{2(\tfrac{x}{x-2})}{(\tfrac{x-x+2}{x-2})} \\
&= \frac{2x}{x-2} \cdot \frac{x-2}{2} \\
&= x
\end{align}
</math>

and that 

<math>
\begin{align}
g(f(x)) &= \frac{\tfrac{2x}{x-1}}{(\tfrac{2x}{x-1})-2} \\
&=  \frac{\tfrac{2x}{x-1}}{(\tfrac{2x-2(x-1)}{x-1})} \\
&= \frac{2x}{x-1} \cdot \frac{x-1}{2} \\
&= x
\end{align}
</math>

and this completes the proof. To see where <math>\displaystyle g(x)</math> came from, check out solution 1.
statement_html:
Prove that the function

\[\begin{aligned} f : \mathbb{R} - \{1\} \to \mathbb{R} - \{2\}\end{aligned}\]

given by

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{2x}{x-1}\end{aligned}\]

is bijective.
statement_raw:
Prove that the function
:<math>
f : \mathbb{R} - \{1\} \to \mathbb{R} - \{2\}
</math>
given by
:<math>
f(x) = \frac{2x}{x-1}
</math>
is bijective.
